grammar_rules.description: Kalenjin verbs are conjugated with prefixes and suffixes for tense and person
Kalenjin has different noun patterns and plural formations
Kalenjin uses tone to distinguish meaning and grammatical functions
examples: High tone vs low tone can change word meaning
Chito ne en kamuktaindet (This person is a teacher)
Chitosiek agobo kole muusik (Many people love music)
Kot ane en koot (My house is big)
Kot ne nee koik angwan (This house has four rooms)
Asom kitabu (I am reading a book)
Biik som skulen (Children study at school)

common_errors.correct: Pay attention to high and low tones
common_errors.example: Tone affects both meaning and grammar

common_errors.correct: Use proper person and tense markers
common_errors.example: Different prefixes for different persons and tenses

common_errors.correct: Learn specific plural patterns for each noun

cultural_context: Kalenjin is spoken by the Kalenjin people of Kenya
It's part of the Nilotic language family
Age-set systems influence language use and respect
Traditional ceremonies and rituals have specific vocabulary
